Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Situation2: They occasionally tidy up visible clutter and do light cleaning in shared spaces.
Story: I was dusting the living room shelves, careful not to miss a spot, when I heard my phone buzz. It was Mia, someone I’d met at a neighbor’s gathering a few weeks ago. She messaged, “Hey! You know the area well, right? Can you recommend a good restaurant for dinner tonight?” As an acquaintance, I felt I should respond quickly and helpfully—after all, that’s what friends, even casual ones, do. But as the housekeeping cleaner, I was on the clock, expected to keep the house spotless and not get distracted. My supervisor had already mentioned that the living room needed extra attention today, and I knew I couldn’t afford to fall behind. I stared at my phone, feeling the pressure from both sides: the urge to be helpful and friendly, and the responsibility to do my job thoroughly. My hands hovered over the phone, torn between sending a quick reply and focusing on the dust cloth in my other hand.
